markdown: The former "HOT Tasking Manager" now [OSM Tasking Manager](https://www.transifex.com/hotosm/osm-tasking-manager2/) is looking for translators.

A workshop was conducted in [CIT](http://www.cittumkur.org/cred_society.html) University, Tumkur. It focused on introducing students to OpenStreetMap, [iD editor](https://www.mapbox.com/blog/get-on-the-map/), the OpenStreetMap Tasking Manager, and [Mapbox Studio](https://www.mapbox.com/mapbox-studio/).

The [Newton hurricane](https://twitter.com/OpenStreetMapMX/status/773329094406569985) struck the area of Southern California. Tasking Manager has been made to facilitate mapping by the community. The red zone is the priority area. The whole area is poorly mapped, so the challenge is strong! Please [help map!](Http://52.41.11.193/osmtm/project/3#task/175)

Severin Menard [initiates](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/hot/2016-October/012536.html) a discussion about necessary improvements to the Tasking Manager to combat the problem of "crappy newbie edits" of humanitarian mappers. A [suggestion](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/hot/2016-October/012540.html) by John Whelan to disable the connection between the Tasking Manager and the iD editor for difficult tasks is not met with disapproval. The quality issue has stuck with the OSM humanitarian community since the Haiti earthquake in 2010 and has been [reoccurring](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/hot/2015-April/008191.html).

Two competing humanitarian mapping organizations are currently operating in Haiti - on the one hand the American HOT US Inc., on the other hand a group of French-speaking mappers, called [Projet EOF](https://projeteof.org/blog/). The latter one has built up, according to their own statements, a local community for the last six years and has contact to the local government. 

HOT US Inc. and the francophone community have been in conflict for [a while](http://www.weeklyosm.eu/archives/6000). Pierre Beland [reminds](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/hot/2016-October/012579.html) that HOT US is blocking postings on the HOT mailing list.

Projet EOF runs it's own [tasking manager](http://taches.francophonelibre.org/). Read here what [happened](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/hot/2016-October/012577.html) as well and conceive your own opinion.

The [disastermappers](https://disastermappers.wordpress.com/) group at the GIScience department of Heidelberg University extracted all the information related to the Missing Maps project from the HOT Tasking Manager and [published](http://k1z.blog.uni-heidelberg.de/2016/10/04/exploring-the-missing-maps-project-%E2%80%93-tasking-manager-statistics/) it on a map.

More discussion about the overlapping tasking managers in Haiti: An email by Rod Bera to the HOT mailing list [explains](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/hot/2016-October/012621.html) why a second tasking manager for humanitarian mapping is required. According to him, the main problem is that [tasks.hotosm.org](http://tasks.hotosm.org/) is under the exclusive control of HOT. Blake Girardot [denies](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/hot/2016-October/012583.html) that, and invites everyone to co-operate over a public Slack channel.

[1] Once again, a devastating earthquake hit 6.6 in Central Italy. _BBC_ [reported](http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-37823614) that thousands of people were left homeless and many buildings destroyed. The Italian community has its own [tasking manager](http://osmit-tm.wmflabs.org/). Please help map Italy!

![Statistik der meisten Edits](http://www.weeklyosm.eu/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/terremoto_italy.jpg) Earthquake in Italy - please map in Italy [^1^](#wn328_13393) |  [OSM Tasking Manager - Wikimedia Italia](http://osmit-tm.wmflabs.org/)
Blake Girardot [calls](https://hotosm.org/updates/2016-12-02_hots_osm_tasking_manager_30_development_kick_off) to participate in the planning, commenting and development of OSM Tasking Manager 3.0.

Martin Dittus (dekstop) [presents](http://www.openstreetmap.org/user/dekstop/diary/40421) the results of his research on how feedback on tasking manager affects the further activity of newcomers. Unfortunately, he does not disclose the rules by which he has classified the individual personal messages.

LearnOSM has been [updated](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/hot/2017-February/012977.html) with some interesting sections which include a guide for anyone to organise a Mapathon, tips aimed at new mappers which include an introduction to iD and tasking manager, and much more.

The Mapbox Data Team [invites you](http://www.openstreetmap.org/user/poornibadrinath/diary/40316) to map points of interest in San Francisco using JOSM with the Mapillary plugin. A comprehensive guide is provided and the project is [open](http://tasks.mapbox.com/project/81) on the Mapbox tasking manager.

Pjstewart1984 [describes](http://www.openstreetmap.org/user/pjstewart1984/diary) in his blog, how the results from [MapSwipe](https://mapswipe.org/) can be used in [OSM Tasking Manager](http://tasks.hotosm.org/).

Russel Deffner has [published](https://twitter.com/weeklyOSM/status/845651495827750914) a [first task](http://tasks.hotosm.org/project/2713) in the OSM Tasking Manager to support the elimination of malaria in Zimbabwe.

The Colombian community [operates](https://tareas.openstreetmap.co/) their own tasking manager. The [donations](http://blog.openstreetmap.co/donations/) (see banner upper left) are going directly to Colombia.

[Vivek Bansal](https://www.linkedin.com/in/3vivekb/), of Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority, [wants](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/talk-us/2017-July/017602.html) to set up a US Tasking Manager task for adding `sidewalk= ` tags across the entire Santa Clara County, California.

OpenStreetMapMx [says](https://twitter.com/weeklyOSM/status/906530028229447681) "Thanks a lot to the digital volunteers mapping #Juchitan". The southern part of the city is already 90% finished, but the north still needs your help: [HOT Tasking Manager](http://tasks.hotosm.org/project/3533)

Christoph Hormann [expresses](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/talk/2017-October/079251.html) on the Talk mailing list, his impressions, and feelings, which he has as a non-Hottie for Tasking Manager 3. It is about the use of the word mark OpenStreetMap. The discussion is [ongoing](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/talk/2017-October/thread.html).
Version 3.0 of the HOT Tasking Manager was released. Read the changes [here](http://tasks.hotosm.org/what-is-new).

John Whelan [complains](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/hot/2017-October/013892.html) on the HOT mailing list about the excessive amount of automatic emails sent by version 3 of the Tasking Manager following a Task evaluation.

[ThinkWhere](http://www.thinkwhere.com/), a Scottish GIS company, [worked](http://futurescot.com/thinkwhere-powers-humanitarian-disaster-response/) with HOT – the Humanitarian OpenStreetMap Team - to develop [version 3 of the Tasking Manager](https://tasks.hotosm.org/).

The eruption of the Mayon volcano in the Philippines is featured on the HOT mailing list. Links to Tasking Manager's tasks can be found in the resulting [discussions](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/hot/2018-January/014160.html).

[Fanga e. V.](http://www.fanga-ev.de/index.php?section=about&language=en), aims to enable the youth in Burkina Faso (West Africa) to receive training and to take care of their medical care. A HOT tasking manager [project](https://tasks.hotosm.org/project/4106?task=370) has been set up to help update the map there.

On 3rd May, two classes from the [Floirac](https://www.openstreetmap.org/relation/88809#map=13/44.8346/-0.4856) school (France) will be on a digital visit to their twin town [Diébougou](https://www.openstreetmap.org/#map=14/10.9654/-3.2382) (Burkina Faso). They [will work](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/hot-francophone/2018-April/001185.html) together with the help of the [tasking manager](http://taches.francophonelibre.org/project/87) provided by [Les Libres Géographes](https://leslibresgeographes.org/dokuwiki/doku.php?id=public:doc_brique_locale) with their partners ([Floirac town hall](http://www.ville-floirac33.fr/), [Num&Lib](https://numetlib.fr/) and [Terre & Océan](http://www.terreetocean.fr/)) to improve the data in OSM.

John Whelan [reports](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/hot/2018-June/014397.html) on the HOT list about duplicate tasks created in the HOT Tasking Manager and creation of duplicate buildings. For some, mapathon organizers should assure training and validation of their participants and inform the coordinators of the humanitarian response of their actions.  This OSM response to the Ebola outbreak is coordinated by OSM-RDC with the DRC Government, the UN Agencies and NGOs in the north of DRC.

We reported [earlier](http://www.weeklyosm.eu/en/archives/10657/#wn423_18271) about a quality analysis tool written by Pierre Béland and used to analyse 12 African cities. The tool has now been used to [analyse](https://opendatalabrdc.github.io/Blog/index.html#!Database_Quality_Analysis_Tasking_Manager.md) 25 Tasking Manager tasks from August. Maps by each contributor allows rapid visualisation to detect those buildings that need to be revised as a matter of priority. Once again there is variability in the quality of building geometries and the number of topological errors. This analysis suggests we need better monitoring tools to follow up on the work done at mapathons by inexperienced mappers.

Sabrina Marx, from the Heidelberg Institute for Geoinformation Technology ([HeiGIT](http://heigit.org)), [published](http://giscienceblog.uni-hd.de/2018/09/05/analyse-hot-tasking-manager-projects-with-the-ohsome-api) a step by step tutorial in a [Jupyter Notebook](https://heigit.org/analyse-hot-tasking-manager-projects-with-the-ohsome-api/) on analysing  HOT Tasking Manager projects using the [ohsome API](http://api.ohsome.org/v0.9/swagger-ui.html).

Matthew Gibb [asked](https://twitter.com/giblet22/status/1050019322142347265) experienced OSM mappers for help with the validation of roads in the Florida Panhandle ahead of Hurricane Michael. A task [was created](https://tasks.openstreetmap.us/project/84) for this on the OSM US tasking manager.

The OpenStreetMap Foundation of Colombia has implemented OSM tools in Spanish (especially for Latin America and Colombia), such as the Tasking Manager and Umap and developed other tools that are hosted in a high availability data centre in Germany. A [fundraising campaign](https://vaki.co/vaki/osmcoytupale) asks for your help to sustain this infrastructure for at least two more years.

The Democratic Republic of Congo suffers from an Ebola outbreak, rebel attacks, and population displacements. With recent imagery, OSM-DRC is active in North-Kivu and opened Tasking Manager jobs. In a mail on the HOT mailing list, Pierre Béland [is recapping](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/hot/2018-December/014662.html) the work from a quality point of view and recommending steps to fix the issues and improve the quality of future mapping activities.

HOT [is asking](https://www.hotosm.org/jobs/rfp-tasking-manager-design-improvements/) for proposals to improve the Tasking Manager. The update will enable the Tasking Manager to incorporate results from machine learning, including a validation and deconflicting process before the model output is pushed to OSM.

The United Nations, in this case the [UN Support Office for Somalia](https://unsos.unmissions.org) (UNSOS), which has been active in Somalia for many years, has recently developed a [mapping initiative](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/UN_Maps_Project) for the country, which is to serve peacekeeping and conflict prevention. In an unusual step for the UN, the organisation has decided to process all data provided directly in OpenStreetMap and thus support all humanitarian institutions. The first project of this initiative is described in the [OSM wiki](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/UN_Maps_Project/UN_maps_for_Somalia) in detail. The [HOT Tasking Manager](https://tasks.hotosm.org/project/5701) will be used for managing this project. The first public mapathon will take place in Italy at the [FOSS4G-IT 2019](http://foss4g-it2019.gfoss.it), as Alessandro P. [posted](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/talk-it/2019-January/065610.html) on the Talk-it mailing list.

HOT has recently [held](https://www.hotosm.org/updates/a-community-of-collaborators-for-the-tasking-manager/) a _Tasking Manager Stakeholders' Workshop_ in Washington, DC at which development goals for 2019 were discussed. The focus will be on the functionality to group users into suitable teams based on the users' backgrounds, statistical features to improve mapping projects and their data quality, the introduction of machine learning workflows into mapping and the observation of usability and user flows.

HOT has [created](https://www.hotosm.org/updates/bringing-machine-learning-and-open-data-to-the-tasking-manager/) a new development community for the Tasking Manager with further partnerships with Microsoft and Bing Maps. Over the next few months, work will begin on the design for integrating machine-learning and improving workflow performance of the Tasking Manager. Additionally open building datasets for Uganda and Tanzania will be created.

During the past months a team of HOT has analysed the mapping and validation workflows of the Tasking Manager to prepare it for the next big update with machine learning and more open data support. In a blog post Leihla Pinho [details](https://www.hotosm.org/updates/tasking-manager-design-discovery/) the undertakings _to improve data quality, increase the speed of mapping, and improve user return rate_.

HOT [shares](https://www.hotosm.org/updates/hands-on-assisted-tasks/) on their blog about an experimental version of the Tasking Manager which incorporates machine learning assistance for various tasks.
HOT [have set](https://tasks-assisted.hotosm.org/) up a Tasking Manager for computer vision imports.

[1] [Mapping North Korea](https://mappingnorthkorea.com/) is a new project from [Maarten van den Hoven](https://maartenvandenhoven.com/) to remotely map North Korea, with a Tasking Manager style web interface.

This work was recently presented at [SotM-Fr 2019](https://twitter.com/nicolas_chavent/status/1139813028034162688). It measures OSM data against open data references like [gROADS](https://sedac.ciesin.columbia.edu/data/collection/groads) to assess the quality and quantity and to find areas which need improvement through [Tasking Manager](https://tasks.hotosm.org/project/1245) projects and [prioritization uMap tasks](http://u.osmfr.org/m/274667/). The developers [are asking](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/hot/2019-June/014906.html) for contributions to this project, started in 2015 and currently covering nine African countries. A [specific Directed Editing sub-page](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Organised_Editing/Activities/Consolidated_mapping_projects_-_base_roads_check_vs_open_data_references) has been created in the OSM wiki.

HOT [is partnering](https://www.hotosm.org/updates/the-machine-learning-enabler/) with Development Seed, Facebook, and Microsoft to build AI-based mapping tools. With the [ML-Enabler](https://github.com/hotosm/ml-enabler), that provides applications such as HOT-'s Tasking Manager the possibility to make use Machine Learning, HOT has reached an important milestone.

The Tasking Manager team has released version v3.4.0 of their software tool for the coordination of volunteers and organisation of groups to
map on OpenStreetMap. The changes in the new version are [detailed](https://github.com/hotosm/tasking-manager/releases/tag/v3.4.0)
in GitHub. People interested in the development can join the [bi-weekly working group meetings](https://github.com/hotosm/tasking-manager/blob/develop/docs/working-group.md).

Felix Delattre presented an [update](https://www.hotosm.org/updates/a-map-editor-for-the-tasking-manager/) on recent work being to improve the HOT Tasking Manager. A user experience survey was carried out in February and March to better understand how users used the software and how users were spending time within the software. Based on the results of the survey HOT plans to better integrate the Tasking Manager with iD in order to improve the experience for mappers and provide user instructions in one tool. This will allow mappers to report back from a task directly from inside the integrated iD editor. Integration also opens the way to dynamically populate the iD editor with tagging presets and specific validation rules depending on the map features that are requested by humanitarian organisations in each of the different projects.

In last week's Pista ng Mapa conference, two sessions were about AI. First was a [lightning talk by Ardie Orden](https://twitter.com/arnalielsewhere/status/1157115191491829763) from Thinking Machines and their Map the Gap initiative, and then a [mapathon](https://twitter.com/maningsambale/status/1157126871403728896) session using Facebook's MapWithAI RapiD editor and HOTOSM's Tasking Manager for areas near the host city of Dumaguete.  During the conference closing activity,  the organisers announced a new initiative to leverage AI-assisted tools for identifying, prioritising, and mapping the road network of the Philippine countryside called [Tabang-AI](https://github.com/OSMPH/Tabang-AI/), a Cebuano word for collaboration, or to aid.

Felix Delattre [informs](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/hot/2019-October/015006.html) us about the development progress of the new HOT Tasking Manager and lays out the current roll-out plan.

OpenStreetMap Croatia started their [own instance of Tasking Manager](https://osm-hr.org/2019/10/16/openstreetmap-hrvatska-je-dobila-tasking-manager/) (automatic [translation](https://translate.google.com/translate?sl

Blog.dedj has given a visual explanation of how to use the [Tasking Manager](https://blog.dedj.be/index.php/post/2019/10/27/Openstreetmap-%3A-Tasks-Manager) ![(fr)](https://blog.openstreetmap.de/wp-uploads/2016/12/fr.svg) (automatic [translation](https://translate.google.com/translate?sl

Felix Delattre [informed](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/hot/2019-November/015044.html) the users of HOT's tasking manager about the unstable state of the tool after a maintenance procedure. The issue came during the worst possible time at the [GeoWeek](https://osmgeoweek.org/) with many planned mapathons. The system was [back online](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/hot/2019-November/015047.html) some hours later.

Felix Delattre [invited](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/hot/2019-December/015082.html) people to sign up if they wanted to help test Tasking Manager 4.  Testing will take place in three phases between now and 8 Febuary.
User qeef tries to [define and offer solutions](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/qeef/diary/391778) to problems with the current HOT Tasking Manager.

Jiri Vlasak [presented](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/talk/2020-January/083761.html) the [Damn-Project](https://www.damn-project.org/) (Divide and Map. Now.) as an alternative to the HOT Tasking Manager. In his blog post he [explains](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/qeef/diary/391778) issues with HOT Tasking Manager and how he proposes solving them.

Russell Deffner, from HOT, [explained](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/hot/2020-March/015154.html) why the organisation has not yet  responded to the Coronavirus threat. Due to missing formal requests from partners, which HOT requires to become active, he suggested organising efforts with local OpenStreetMap Chapters and Communities and to use HOT resources, such as the Tasking Manager, if needed.

...the [OSM Ireland Tasking Manager](https://tasks.openstreetmap.ie), which was set up to complete all of Ireland’s buildings in OSM as part of the [#osmIRL_buildings](https://twitter.com/hashtag/osmIRL_buildings) campaign.

The HOT NGO has [released](https://www.hotosm.org/updates/tasking-manager-gets-a-makeover/) Tasking Manager version 4. All improvements are detailed in the [release notes](https://github.com/hotosm/tasking-manager/releases/tag/v4.0.0). The new version is available in the [source code repository](https://github.com/hotosm/tasking-manager) and on 6 May, the new version will be launched on the [HOT Tasking Manager](https://tasks.hotosm.org).

... [UN Mappers](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Unite_Maps_Initiative/UN_Mappers)?  It is a newly created but growing community of mappers that contributes to the United Nations' peace-building and humanitarian efforts (we [reported](https://www.weeklyosm.eu/en/archives/13046/#wn507_22256)) by editing OSM features in developing countries with the goal of producing better data and maps for daily [UN operational activities](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Unite_Maps_Initiative). A large number of mapping projects [are available](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Unite_Maps_Initiative/UN_Mappers#Mapathons_and_Events) on the Tasking Manager under 'UN Mappers'.

HOT [presented](https://www.hotosm.org/updates/tm4launch/) the new Tasking Manager. The improved frontend with integrated iD editor and mapping roles such as Validators, Mapper and Project Manager are intended to assist collaborative mapping.

The [Transatlantic Council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Scouting_overseas#Transatlantic_Council) of Boy Scouts of America organised a five-day [Virtual Mapathon Challenge](https://www.pr.com/press-release/812294), allowing [Sea Scouts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sea_Scouts_%28Boy_Scouts_of_America%29) to complete community service requirements by completing tasks on the HOT Tasking Manager.

In a blogpost Mikel Maron, Lead Mapbox Community team, co-founder of HOT and OSMF board member, [published](https://blog.mapbox.com/hots-tasking-manager-4-how-we-built-it-53ebaa3cafd0) an interview with the Tasking Manager’s lead developer, Felix Delattre, on technical details and other background information of the new version of HOT's widely used tool.

An [interview](https://www.hotosm.org/updates/tasking-manager-behind-the-devdesk-with-wille-marcel/) with Wille Marcel focuses on his work helping to develop the new release (4.0) of the HOT Tasking Manager.

A service similar to the Tasking Manager, which breaks an area into smaller chunks that humans can map, is ['Divide and map. Now'](https://www.damn-project.org/). In a diary post, user qeef [writes](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/qeef/diary/393240) about the experiences he had in setting up the service on an inexpensive VPS and testing it with 100 mappers.

[hauke-stieler](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/hauke-stieler) has developed a new [task management tool](https://stm.hauke-stieler.de), as an alternative to the HOT tasking manager or MapCraft, and called it Simple Task Manager (STM). On the mailing list Hauke [explains](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/talk-de/2020-July/116890.html) ![(de)](https://blog.openstreetmap.de/wp-uploads/2016/12/de.svg) (automatic [translation](https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=auto&tl=EN&u=https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/talk-de/2020-July/116890.html)) in detail what made him do it and how to work with the STM.

With the release of the latest version of iD, the 'locator overlay', a semi-transparent overlay when zoomed out, [has been rebuilt](https://blog.mapbox.com/rebuilt-locator-overlay-for-id-editor-9606da7f18f8). Via the OpenStreetMap editor-layer-index, the new overlay is now available on OpenStreetMap.org, and soon on the HOT Tasking Manager and other instances of iD.

Michael Montani, from the UN Department of Operational Support, [invited](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/talk-ml/2020-September/000248.html) ![(fr)](https://blog.openstreetmap.de/wp-uploads/2016/12/fr.svg) > [![en](https://weeklyosm.eu/wp-content/uploads/sites/4/2020/09/en-green.svg)](https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=auto&tl=EN&u=https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/talk-ml/2020-September/000248.html) OSM contributors, on various African local discussion lists, to help support UN missions. Mappers can do this by participating in the Tasking Manager jobs they have created to map highways, waterways, land cover, land use, places, and any other relevant points of interest.

Russ Deffner has [called](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/hot/2020-October/015363.html) on the OSM community to take action against COVID-19, by contributing to one of HOT's projects either on their Tasking Manager or Mapswipe.

The [UN Mappers](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Unite_Maps_Initiative/UN_Mappers) ('Mapping the #world and serving humanity') have set up a task on HOT's Tasking Manager [to map](https://tasks.hotosm.org/projects/9310) roads, waterways, and villages in Somalia.

OSM Ireland now [offers](https://tasks.openstreetmap.ie/project/26) a Tasking Manager that organises the simultaneous mapping of buildings close to each other, by multiple mappers, by assigning the mappers different squares to work on. Another possibility is to start your own projects anywhere in the world.

The Collective for the Protection of Sugamuxi Province requested support from OpenStreetMap Colombia and its Tasking Manager to update the map of the [Lake Tota Basin](https://tareas.openstreetmap.co/project/175). High levels of lead contamination alarmed the population and the authorities, who still do not know the origin of this heavy metal in the ecosystem. [The map update](https://entreojos.co/item/507-a-traves-openstreetmap-buscan-identificar-fuentes-de-contaminacion-en-el-lago-de-tota) ![(es)](https://blog.openstreetmap.de/wp-uploads/2016/12/es.svg) > [![en](https://weeklyosm.eu/wp-content/uploads/sites/4/2020/09/en-green.svg)](https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=auto&tl=EN&u=https://entreojos.co/item/507-a-traves-openstreetmap-buscan-identificar-fuentes-de-contaminacion-en-el-lago-de-tota) aims to help identify and solve the health and environmental problems of the second largest lake in the Andes.

Pete Masters [shared](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/pedrito1414/diary/395256) an OSM diary on 'Potential HOT tasking manager improvements to help new and existing contributors collaborate more effectively'.

OpenStreetMap Ghana is mapping Accra to increase map coverage in the capital. This is to support Ministries, Metropolitan Municipal and District Assemblies, local organisations, individuals and other stakeholders by giving them access to quality map data. You can contribute to this [project ](https://tasks.hotosm.org/projects/9928) through the HOT Tasking Manager.

GIScience News Blog: [Humanitarian OSM Stats](http://k1z.blog.uni-heidelberg.de/2021/01/27/humanitarian-osm-stats-how-to-monitor-humanitarian-mapping-in-the-hot-tasking-manager-part-1/): How to [monitor](https://humstats.heigit.org/) humanitarian mapping in the HOT Tasking Manager?

Benjamin Herfort, from Heidelberg University, [reported](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/hot/2021-February/015478.html) about global indicators of mapping related to the [HOT Tasking Manager](https://tasks.hotosm.org/). Analysis in an associated [blog post](http://k1z.blog.uni-heidelberg.de/2021/02/04/the-evolution-of-humanitarian-mapping-within-the-openstreetmap-community/) lets us see the progression in the number of contributors since 2012 followed by a decline since 2017. No breakdown of contributors by experience (i.e. days of contribution, objects edited, etc.) is given. The author notes that to associate all these tasks with humanitarian mapping (or all humanitarian mapping with only these tasks) is therefore an oversimplified definition and the results must be taken with a grain of salt.

Benjamin Herfort [describes](http://k1z.blog.uni-heidelberg.de/2021/03/10/humanitarian-osm-stats-how-to-monitor-humanitarian-mapping-in-the-hot-tasking-manager-part-4/)  in part 4 of 'How to monitor humanitarian mapping in the HOT Tasking Manager' the global statistics available – such as the number of projects, participants, buildings, roads, etc. – and the various possibilities to dig into these metadata.

A UK contributor used MapUganda to create Humanitarian Mapping tasks for Merthyr Tidfil, Wales in the UK and justified their changes by citing the most alarming COVID-19 metrics in the UK. UK contributors were not consulted prior to these actions and some contributors are upset by the  lack of communication and transparency,  and poor mapping quality, such as retagging residential roads as motorways ([example](https://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/102440180)) ([see discussion](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/talk-gb/2021-April/026664.html)). Richard Fairhurst asked that the mapping activity be paused. He doubts the rationale of the task because the local Director of Public Health should have access to authoritative building footprints. It appears the projects have now been removed from the tasking manager.

Gloria Urrea, University of Colorado at Boulder, and Eunae Yoo, University of Tennessee, partnered with HOT to conduct research that has produced insights for HOT and the other organisations that use the Tasking Manager. Here, they [summarise](https://www.hotosm.org/updates/how-users-experience-impacts-project-completion-and-retention/) their research project, which examines the impact of users’ experience on project completion and retention.

... that non-square buildings are not the only kind of quality issue with mapped buildings on OSM? [Berrely](http://hdyc.neis-one.org/?Berrely) reported, on Discord, that he had found [grouped multiple buildings](https://www.openstreetmap.org/relation/11818325#map=19/38.50972/27.07064) in a relation with the `building=yes` tag applied to the relation and not the ways.  This was related to the tasking manager project [tasks.hotosm.org/projects/9717](https://tasks.hotosm.org/projects/9717), which is no longer available, about the Izmir earthquake response, Turkey, a year ago.

The HOT [Field Mapping Tasking Manager](https://fmtm.hotosm.org/project_details/MTAxMTAxMA==) example (background OSM map without attribution) shows how a Server and a Mobile tool from the ODK suite are used to coordinate field teams and collect data from the field. These two tools are available free and open source for any organisation that wants to deploy its own server. Paid hosted services are also available.

- The ODK Central server stores survey data and lets teams coordinate field data collection. Entities can be stored with geometry and properties.
- The Android ODK Collect application can be used offline to collect data in the field.

Mikko Tamura [reported](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/13bhdTjEINsXJtb4vaKbcjinBCjKJcKG_YDYdoxZACl4/edit?gid=1843614733#gid=1843614733) that in the span of just three weeks, since the [OM Guru Climate Change Challenge 2024](https://www.facebook.com/reel/1181265026226030) began, more than 250,000 buildings, 11,000 km of roads, 15,000 POIs, and 8,000 km of waterways have been mapped. More than 4 million tiles were swiped, 11,000 Tasking Manager tasks completed, and 16,000 MapRoulette tasks finished.

Herrera-Murillo et al. have [published](https://agile-giss.copernicus.org/articles/5/5/2024/) a conference paper titled 'Process Analysis in Humanitarian Voluntary Geographic Information: the case of the HOT Tasking Manager', in which they analyse two years of individual contributors' actions from the Tasking Manager logs, and process them from the perspectives of control flow, time, organisation, and outcomes of the mapping tasks that comprise a project. OSM data is also extracted for the analysis from the Bunting Labs OSM [extracts](https://buntinglabs.com/solutions/openstreetmap-extracts) service.

The campaign to map the flooded areas in the State of Rio Grande do Sul (Brazil) [continues](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/2024_Rio_Grande_do_Sul_Floods) and mappers from all over the world are invited to collaborate on the open projects in the HOT Tasking Manager. Links to the projects and other information can be found on the campaign's wiki page.

Gregory Peony [shared](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/Gregory%20Peony/diary/404695) a tip on how to provide efficient feedback to contributors in Tasking Manager projects as a validator.

Prabinoid described moving Tasking Manager from Flask to FastAPI and from psycopg2 to asyncpg. This aimed to [improve](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/prabinoid/diary/404704) performance and scalability by using asynchronous programming, modern Python features and optimised database interactions. Despite challenges like learning the new system and changing code, he stated in a community discussion that the move [offers](https://community.openstreetmap.org/t/migrating-tasking-manager-from-flask-to-fastapi-and-psycopg2-to-asyncpg/116543) benefits including better throughput and simpler API development.

Sujan Adhikari [explained](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/Sujan%20Adhikari/diary/405099) HOT's 'Field Mapping and Tasking Manager Splitter' algorithm. This algorithm simplifies field mapping by breaking down areas of interest into smaller manageable tasks for mappers.

HOTOSM's tech updates for November 2024 highlighted ongoing projects, including the alpha launch of [Drone Tasking Manager](https://dronetm.org/) with OpenDroneMap integration, testing of FastAPI for the Tasking Manager, and development of [fAIr 2.0](https://fair.hotosm.org/) with YOLOv8 model for building detection, as well as improvements to [uMap authentication](https://umap.hotosm.org/en/).

Contributors can [support](https://tasks.hotosm.org/projects/18320)  the OSM France project for Mayotte response via the tasking manager to support the response and recovery efforts in the Island after the passage of cyclone Chido. Only intermediate and advanced OSM users can contribute in this project. The HOT Open Mapping Hub ESA is inviting contributors to [map](https://tasks.hotosm.org/projects/18313) for nearby Mozambique, where mappers of all levels of experience can contribute.

Eleven Landesamt für Geoinformation und Landesvermessung Niedersachsen (Hannover Germany) trainees have [supported](https://www.kreiszeitung.de/lokales/diepholz/sulingen-ort50128/lgln-azubis-im-kartierungseinsatz-fuer-missing-maps-93569989.html) :DE-s:>>>[:EN-t:](https://www-kreiszeitung-de.translate.goog/lokales/diepholz/sulingen-ort50128/lgln-azubis-im-kartierungseinsatz-fuer-missing-maps-93569989.html?_x_tr_sl=auto&_x_tr_tl=EN) the [Missing Maps](https://www.missingmaps.org/) project by mapping 1387 buildings in OpenStreetMap to aid humanitarian efforts. Guided by the German Red Cross, they focused on flood-prone areas near Montréal and other global regions, gaining valuable technical and social insights.
